facts.text: Petitioners are seven in number: first petitioner is a registered firm, petitioners Nos. 2 to 6 are partners, petitioner No. 7 is General Manager holding public carrier permit for whole of Rajasthan.
Petitioners hold 59 stage carriage permits from Regional Transport Authority, Jodhpur, for diverse routes over roads with different surfaces (sandy or katcha, metalled, tarred etc.).
Rajasthan Passengers and Goods Taxation Act, 1959 enacted for levying tax on passengers and goods carried by road in motor vehicles, derived from Entry 56 State List.
Act received President's assent on April 27, 1959, published April 30, 1959; Rules and notification issued same day; Act effective May 1, 1959.
Rules subsequently amended; challenge concerns amended Rules.

Section 3: Charging section levies tax on fares and freights not exceeding 1/8 on better roads, 1/12 on others; minimum 1 naya paisa; Explanation covers free carriage, lump sums, inter-state journeys.
Proviso to s.3(1): For intra-state journeys through another state, tax on full fare/freight.
Section 4: Tax collected by owner; provisos allow State to accept lump sum for public carriers and contract carriages.
Notification under Rule 8 fixes lump sum rates for public carriers/goods vehicles based on permit type and load capacity (e.g., Rs.420-540 per annum).
Petition under Art.32 challenging Act, Rules, notification as unconstitutional.
No exemptions granted under s.9 except to hospitals or charities.
Lump sum rates work out to less than Re.1 per day minimum, Rs.1.50 nP. maximum.

legal_issues.text: Whether tax under Act is on passengers/goods (Entry 56) or on fares/freights (ultra vires).
Whether Act/Rules repugnant to Arts. 301, 304 (restriction on inter-state trade).
Whether unreasonable restriction on business under Art.19(1)(g).
Whether discriminates under Art.14 between road transport and railways.
Whether power to fix lump sums lacks guidance.
Whether Rules 8, 8A and notification make lump sum compulsory, exceeding Act.
Whether higher tax on better roads discriminates.
Whether proviso to s.3(1) has extra-territorial operation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tax laid on fares/freights, not passengers/goods; differs from Entry 56, cf. Entry 89 Union List.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 56 State List; Entry 89 Union List

petitioner_arguments.text: Repugnant to Arts.301,304 as restriction on inter-state trade/commerce.
Unreasonable restriction on business under Art.19.
Power to fix lump sums without guidance.
Rules 8,8A, notification make lump sum compulsory though Act optional; tax even without passengers/goods.
Higher rates for better roads discriminate between operators.

respondent_arguments.text: Lump sum rates reasonable (min <Re.1/day, max Rs.1.50nP/day).

court_reasoning.text: Tax in pith and substance on passengers/goods, measured by fares/freights; Explanation confirms incidence on passengers/goods even if free.
No impact on inter-state trade; tax only on intra-state portion except specified proviso; no offence to Arts.301,304.
Rules/notifications permissive, harmonious with s.4; 'shall' fixes amount if option chosen; not compulsory.
Lump sum based on averages from fares fixed under MV Act; optional; reasonable.
No discrimination vs railways (Union subject); all road operators equal.
Higher tax on better roads justified by construction/maintenance costs; no discrimination between comparable persons.
Proviso s.3(1) not extra-territorial; no evidence of such routes.

holdings.text: Act within Entry 56; tax on passengers/goods.
Rules 8,8A, notification valid, not exceeding Act.
No discrimination; lump sum power guided.

precedents_cited.relevance: Tax measured by fares/freights still on passengers/goods.

precedents_cited.case_name: Atma Ram Budhia v. State of Bihar
In re Lord Thurlow Ex Parte Official Receiver
Burjore and Bhavani Pershad v. Mussumat Bhagana

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis of petition; competence; freedoms; equality.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Passengers and Goods Taxation Act, 1959
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged provisions on levy, collection, lump sum, exemptions.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Passengers and Goods Taxation Rules, 1959

outcome.summary: All contentions rejected; Act, Rules, notification held constitutional and valid.

key_quotes.text: "Section 3, in terms, speaks of the charge of the tax in respect of all passengers carried and goods transported by motor vehicles, and though the measure of the tax is furnished by the amount of fare and freight charged. it does number cease to be a tax on passengers and goods."
